<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 278, 905, 293]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 299, 905, 314]]<|/det|>
May/June 2019

1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 502, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 546]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 604, 571]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 759, 586]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 759, 91]]<|/det|>
Some students are determining the mass of a block U by a balancing method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 514, 122]]<|/det|>
They are using the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 135, 927, 285]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 303, 532, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 335, 146, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
One student places the metre rule on the pivot at the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and then places block U with its centre at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
Suggest why it might be difficult to place block U accurately at the \(5.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Explain how the student could overcome this difficulty. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 597, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
The student places block M on the metre rule as shown in Fig. 1.1 and adjusts the position of block M until the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 644, 920, 677]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe a method to find the position at which the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible.

He also determines the distance \(b\) between the centre of block U and the centre of block M. <label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the transfer of thermal energy between hot water in a beaker and cold water in a glass boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 484, 137]]<|/det|>
He is using the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 147, 850, 521]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 536, 532, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 146, 586]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 813, 586]]<|/det|>
Record the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\), shown on the thermometer in the boiling tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 597, 922, 617]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .......................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 629, 813, 648]]<|/det|>
The student pours cold water into the boiling tube and hot water into the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 606, 662]]<|/det|>
He places the boiling tube into the beaker of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 658, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
He then records the temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{C}}\) of the water in the boiling tube and the temperatures \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the water in the beaker every \(30 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 706, 458, 725]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[190, 72, 625, 91]]<|/det|>
The circuit components are to be rearranged so that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 103, 515, 121]]<|/det|>
• resistors X, Y and Z are in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 120, 646, 137]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 813, 152]]<|/det|>
• the voltmeter will measure the potential difference across the resistors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 601, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 490, 918, 523]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A student wants to investigate the factors that affect the height to which a ball bounces when it is dropped.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment that will enable him to investigate in detail how the height from which a ball is dropped affects how high it bounces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 398, 183]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 455, 213]]<|/det|>
balls of different materials and sizes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 437, 228]]<|/det|>
sheets of different floor coverings.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 242, 378, 260]]<|/det|>
Write a plan for the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 274, 324, 291]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 305, 457, 322]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 608, 354]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the experiment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
· describe a precaution which could be taken to ensure that measurements of the height of bounce are reliable

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 414, 531, 432]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 445, 831, 478]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 491, 712, 509]]<|/det|>
· explain how you could analyse your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 576, 539]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.
